comment:
Hasting. August,5 - September,2 1895. A prestigious tournament,
organized in order to compare the playing strength of the top chess champions
at that time. Chigorin, Lasker, Tarrasch, Steinitz, Schlechter and other 17
players were participating. All of them were very strong players. Among them
Janowsky and a new talented american player Harry Nelson Pillsbury, who won
the tournament with 16.5 points out of 21. Janowsky, for various reasons not
at his best playing strength, was however successfull in defending his
reputation he had gained in Paris.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7
comment:
Steinitz, always faithful to his favoured defense, this time has
improved it with the move a7-a6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4
comment:
What is that? Some strange impulse or a new idea? Janowsky seems ready
to give his lightsquare Bishop for the sake of attack. Is that too much?
Pillsbury, categorically, commented: "Such a move should cost the game to
White."

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5
comment:
(?) Pillsbury again: "Probably this
exchange is a real mistake. A deadly mistake, I would say. After 9...Bxf5 10.
exf5 White would have lost a piece without compensation." Is it possible that
both Janowsky and Steinitz overlooked the simple continuation suggested by
Pillsbury? Uhmm ... hard to believe.  And in fact, the moves 9... Bxf5 10.
exf5 c4 11. Nc3 (!)  cxb3 12. axb3  followed  by Rf1-e1 and Nc3-d5 (or Nc3-e4)
should make worry the Black's conductor. Let's say that his position, with the
King in the middle of the chessboard, half-undressed, seems at least unclear.
Open windows and doors create air currents which are dangerous for healt. If,
for instance, 12...Nxf5 then 13.Qd5 would win the piece back with advantage.
If then White would play at once 11.Re1, Black, before taking the Bishop,
should scratch his head and think about it one, two, ten times before doing it.
Maybe Pillsbury, with the presumption tha can be told from his words, did "pee
counter wind", to use an italian expression.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3
comment: Of course now it is too late to play 10...c4 because of 11.Qe2+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+
comment:
Maybe Steinitz has been too quick in willing to eliminate
the dangerous lightsquare Bishop. Maybe, probably, surely indeed, Janowsky
will show us that his opponent "fell out the frying pan into the fire"!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5
comment:
Perhaps, as a last attempt to stop the imminent
catastrophe, Steinitz could have tried 13...Be6 14.Qh5 Qd7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6
comment:
It is a bit difficult to think that Black could have escaped by sacrificing a
Rook for a minor piece: 14...0-0 15.Bh6. And what if Steinitz wanted to save
this too playing 15...Re8?  Then after 16.Nc3 he could have left the table and
go sell nuts and beans at the Astor movie theather in his hometown.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6 15. Nc3 Be6 16. Nb5
comment:
(!!) How does it begin the Fifth Simphony of Beethoven? Da-da-da..
.dawn! The "theme of destiny"!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6 15. Nc3 Be6 16. Nb5 Qc6 17. Rxe6 Qxb5 18. Bh6 Kd8 19. Qxf7 Re8 20. Rae1
comment:
Is it clear that White is aiming the "e7" and "f6" squares? No?
Ok, let's go on.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6 15. Nc3 Be6 16. Nb5 Qc6 17. Rxe6 Qxb5 18. Bh6 Kd8 19. Qxf7 Re8 20. Rae1 Qd7 21. Bg7

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6 15. Nc3 Be6 16. Nb5 Qc6 17. Rxe6 Qxb5 18. Bh6 Kd8 19. Qxf7 Re8 20. Rae1 Qd7 21. Bg7 Rc8 22. Bxf6 Bxf6 23. Qxf6+
comment: The shortest way. Now one could announce mate in seven (Fritz says).

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 d6 5. O-O Ne7 6. Bb3 Na5 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 c5 9. Nf5 Nxf5 10. exf5 Nxb3 11. Re1+ Be7 12. f6 gxf6 13. axb3 d5 14. Qh5 Qd6 15. Nc3 Be6 16. Nb5 Qc6 17. Rxe6 Qxb5 18. Bh6 Kd8 19. Qxf7 Re8 20. Rae1 Qd7 21. Bg7 Rc8 22. Bxf6 Bxf6 23. Qxf6+ Kc7 24. Qe5+
